carousel.sintesis: The dominant narrative in Latin America revolves around the US military intervention in Venezuela, the capture of Nicolás Maduro, and the ensuing political and geopolitical ramifications. There are widespread reactions, ranging from celebration by the Venezuelan diaspora to condemnation from regional allies and international bodies, focusing on the implications for Venezuela's sovereignty and regional stability.
carousel.sintesis_en: The dominant narrative in Latin America revolves around the US military intervention in Venezuela, the capture of Nicolás Maduro, and the ensuing political and geopolitical ramifications. There are widespread reactions, ranging from celebration by the Venezuelan diaspora to condemnation from regional allies and international bodies, focusing on the implications for Venezuela's sovereignty and regional stability.

particulas.title: Editorial: Legalidad internacional destruida
particulas.titulo_es: Editorial: Legalidad internacional destruida
particulas.titulo_en: Editorial: Legalidad internacional destruida
particulas.description: En las primeras horas de ayer, el mundo asistió al más reciente episodio de la destrucción sistemática de la legalidad internacional emprendida por la administración de Donald Trump desde sus inicios. Sin el menor argumento, fuerzas militares de Estados Unidos lanzaron un bombardeo sobre la capital de Venezuela y otras localidades de ese país, secuestraron al presidente Nicolás Maduro y a su esposa, Cilia Flores, y se los llevaron con rumbo desconocido.

Bombardearon distintos puntos estratégicos de ese país. Dañaron infraestructura. Asesinaron a militares, civiles y secuestraron al presidente de la República Bolivariana de Venezuela, Nicolás Maduro Moros y a su esposa, Cilia Flores. particulas.titulo_en: “Venezuela sólo puede alegrarse del fin de la dictadura”, declara Macron
particulas.description: París. El presidente de Francia, Emmanuel Macron, declaró ayer que el “pueblo venezolano” sólo puede “alegrarse” del fin de la “dictadura (del presidente Nicolás) Maduro”, y reclamó una “transición pacífica” del poder en la república bolivariana. Antes, su canciller, Jean-Noël Barrot, afirmó que la operación militar que llevó al secuestro de Maduro “contraviene el principio de no uso de la fuerza, fundamental para el derecho internacional”.

particulas.titulo_en: Swiss investigate bar Le Constellation managers

particulas.title: Russia makes largest territorial gains in Ukraine since 2022 invasion
particulas.titulo_es: Russia makes largest territorial gains in Ukraine since 2022 invasion
particulas.titulo_en: Russia makes largest territorial gains in Ukraine since 2022 invasion
particulas.description: Russia captured more than 5,600 sq km of Ukrainian territory in 2025, its largest advance since 2022, as Kyiv prepares to host allied security talks. As pressure on the battlefield continues to build, President Volodymyr Zelensky named Kyrylo Budanov his new top aide, proposed Mykhailo Fedorov as defence minister and ordered the evacuation of thousands from frontline settlements.

particulas.title: Secret operation unveiled: Ukraine fakes death of anti-Kremlin Russian fighter
particulas.titulo_es: Secret operation unveiled: Ukraine fakes death of anti-Kremlin Russian fighter
particulas.titulo_en: Secret operation unveiled: Ukraine fakes death of anti-Kremlin Russian fighter
particulas.description:
Ukraine staged the death of an anti-Kremlin Russian fighter, Denis Kapustin, to prevent his killing ordered by Moscow's special forces, Ukrainian military intelligence announced Thursday.
 
His assassination, GUR said in a statement, "was ordered by the special services of the aggressor state Russia, which allocated half a million dollars to carry out the crime."

particulas.title: Crans-Montana fire likely caused by sparklers on Champagne bottles
particulas.titulo_es: Crans-Montana fire likely caused by sparklers on Champagne bottles
particulas.titulo_en: Crans-Montana fire likely caused by sparklers on Champagne bottles
particulas.description: Initial investigations ​suggest that ⁠the fire which tore through a Swiss ski resort ​bar started ‍when 'fountain candles' attached ​to champagne bottles were carried ​aloft too close to the ceiling, the local prosecutor said on Friday. Authorities planned to look into whether the material on the ceiling that was designed to muffle sound conformed with regulations. FRANCE 24's Olivia Bizot is on the ground.

particulas.title: A fire in a Swiss ski resort bar kills 40 people: What we know so far
particulas.titulo_es: A fire in a Swiss ski resort bar kills 40 people: What we know so far
particulas.titulo_en: A fire in a Swiss ski resort bar kills 40 people: What we know so far
particulas.description:
Swiss investigators are probing what caused a fire in a bar at an Alpine ski resort that left around 40 people dead and another 115 injured during a New Year's celebration.
 
Most injuries, many of them serious, occurred when the blaze swept through the crowded bar less than two hours after midnight in southwestern Switzerland.

particulas.title: Crans-Montana fire: what we know so far about how it could have started
particulas.titulo_es: Crans-Montana fire: what we know so far about how it could have started
particulas.titulo_en: Crans-Montana fire: what we know so far about how it could have started
particulas.description: Switzerland is reeling from the deadly fire in ski resort Crans-Montana. Some 47 people were killed on New Years eve, more than one hundred people were severely burned. The first emergency is to treat the wounded and identify victims. Authorities are also investigating what caused the fire and whether the bar violated security norms.

particulas.title: First victim of Crans-Montana fire identified as investigations continue
particulas.titulo_es: First victim of Crans-Montana fire identified as investigations continue
particulas.titulo_en: First victim of Crans-Montana fire identified as investigations continue
particulas.description: Investigations into the victims of the Crans-Montana fire are still ongoing, with authorities having revealed one identity so far. It could take weeks before they are able to confirm identities and nationalities of the victims due to the severity of the burns. In the meantime, five days of national mourning have been announced. FRANCE 24's Olivia Bizot tell us more live from Crans-Montana.

particulas.title: Rights group says at least 16 dead in Iran during week of protests
particulas.titulo_es: Rights group says at least 16 dead in Iran during week of protests
particulas.titulo_en: Rights group says at least 16 dead in Iran during week of protests
particulas.description: By Elwely ElwellyDUBAI, Jan 4 (Reuters) - At least 16 people have been killed during a week of unrest in Iran, rights groups said on Sunday, as protests over soaring inflation spread across the country prompting violent clashes between demonstrators and security forces. Deaths and arrests have been reported through the week both by state media and rights groups, though the numbers have differed. Reuters has not been able to verify the figures independently.

particulas.description: CAIRO, Jan 4 (Reuters) - Israeli forces shot and killed at least three Palestinians in separate incidents in the southern Gaza Strip city of Khan Younis on Sunday, local health authorities said.Medics reported that the dead included a 15‑year‑old boy, a fisherman killed outside areas still occupied by Israel in the enclave, and a third man who was shot and killed east of the city in areas under Israeli control.The Israeli military had no immediate comment on the reported incidents.

particulas.titulo_en: Sudanese flee across border and back to escape overrun oil town
particulas.description: When paramilitary fighters closed in on the Sudanese border town and oil field of Heglig, paraplegic Dowa Hamed could only cling to her husband's back as they fled, "like a child", she told AFP.Now, the 25-year-old mother of five -- paralysed from the waist down -- lies shell-shocked on a cot in the Abu al-Naga displacement camp, a dusty transit centre just outside the eastern city of Gedaref, nearly 800 kilometres (500 miles) from home.

particulas.description: DUBAI, Jan 3 (Reuters) - Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei vowed not to yield after U.S. President Donald Trump threatened to come to the aid of protesters, as rights groups reported a sharp rise in arrests following days of unrest sparked by soaring inflation.Speaking in a recorded appearance on television on Saturday, Khamenei said the Islamic Republic "will not yield to the enemy" and said rioters should be "put in their place".

particulas.titulo_es: Iran's Khamenei says protesters' economic demands fair, warns 'rioters'
particulas.titulo_en: Iran's Khamenei says protesters' economic demands fair, warns 'rioters'
particulas.description: Supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei on Saturday acknowledged the economic demands of protesters in Iran, where demonstrations have spread to more than two dozen cities, even as he warned there would be no quarter for "rioters".The protests began on Sunday as an expression of discontent over high prices and economic stagnation, but have since expanded to include political demands.Iranian media have reported localised violence and vandalism in the west of the country in recent days.

particulas.description:
A decade ago, Samantha Ong would go to the cinemas in Singapore twice a week. She now goes about once a month, opting instead to watch films on Netflix at home.
“Sometimes it doesn’t feel worth it to spend three hours on a movie, so it’s better to watch it at home where there is an option to fast-forward,” said Ong, 26. “I have to juggle working out and meeting up with friends in my free time, so I’ll go [to the cinema] only if I really want the full experience.”

particulas.titulo_en: How China quietly became the world’s climate policy leader
particulas.description:
In contrast to the United States, which innovates and influences, and the European Union, which regulates, China has become the world’s climate doer.

particulas.title: Africa: HIV Funding Still Falls Short of Targets After Pledges - What's At Stake
particulas.titulo_es: Africa: HIV Funding Still Falls Short of Targets After Pledges - What's At Stake
particulas.titulo_en: Africa: HIV Funding Still Falls Short of Targets After Pledges - What's At Stake
particulas.description: [The Conversation Africa] The US government paused all foreign assistance in January 2025. This abrupt decision affected the delivery of life-saving HIV medicines and the provision of HIV prevention services to millions of people. A UNAIDS report estimates there could be an additional 6 million new HIV infections and 4 million Aids-related deaths by 2029 if the world does not act.

particulas.titulo_en: Nigeria: Reforms Meet Politics in a High-Stakes Economic Year
particulas.description: [This Day] Nigeria reached 2026 at a delicate crossroads, balancing hard-won economic stabilisation against the rising pull of pre-election politics. Inflation has eased, the naira has steadied, and reforms are moving from design to execution, yet campaign spending and fiscal pressures are already gathering force. This is a year when budgets, markets, and institutions will be tested simultaneously. How policy discipline holds under political strain will shape business assurance and economic outc

particulas.description: [Leadership] The United States (US) Christmas Day bombing of ISIS-linked terrorist camps in Sokoto State has opened a vista of complicated issues and a deepening world -wide intervention that will likely employ extreme measures against the terrorists' sympathisers, financiers, ideologues and enablers in Nigeria.

particulas.title: Liberia: Liberia Returns to the UN Security Council After 64 Years
particulas.titulo_es: Liberia: Liberia Returns to the UN Security Council After 64 Years
particulas.titulo_en: Liberia: Liberia Returns to the UN Security Council After 64 Years
particulas.description: [Liberian Observer] Sixty-four years after it last sat at the world's most powerful peace and security table, Liberia on Friday formally reclaimed its place on the United Nations Security Council (UNSC), marking a watershed moment in the country's diplomatic history and underscoring what many observers describe as the single most significant foreign policy achievement of the Boakai administration so far.

particulas.description: [Vanguard] Living costs differ significantly across Africa, shaped by factors such as import dependence, currency strength, urbanisation and consumer demand. While some countries remain relatively affordable, others stand out for their high day-to-day expenses--particularly for food, dining, transport and utilities.

carousel.sintesis: The dominant narrative revolves around the escalating conflict in Ukraine, its multifaceted impact on Russia and Europe, and the intervention of external actors like the US and China, particularly regarding peace talks and security guarantees. Also, there's increasing instability in Venezuela due to US intervention and the global response.
